questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with gait instability and a premonition of falling while standing that faded while he walked, sat, or lay down. He doesn't have tremors elsewhere in the body. There is no history of mental illness or psychotropic drug usage. On examination, fine ripples are noted over the area of the quadriceps muscle while standing. Based on the above clinical findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's history of tremors that increase on standing with relief on walking as well as ripples in the quadriceps muscles on standing makes a diagnosis of orthostatic tremor likely.

Orthostatic tremor is characterized by a tremor that mostly affects the lower extremities, exhibiting high frequency and low amplitude. Frequently, individuals experience symptoms of shakiness or unsteadiness while assuming an upright position and commonly express relief after transitioning to a seated or ambulatory state. Falls are often observed occurrences.

The tremor can typically be detected by palpating the lower extremities while assuming an upright posture. Some authors consider this entity as a variant of essential tremor. Multiple studies have demonstrated the efficacy of Levodopa, Gabapentin and Clonazepam in the treatment of Orthostatic tremors.

Other options:

Option B: Degeneration of substantia nigra is seen in Parkinson's disease, also known as paralysis agitans. It shows an accumulation of synucleins. Bradykinesia, rigidity, resting tremors, and postural instability are classic features of Parkinson's disease. Lack of tremors in other regions of the body as well as the absence of bradykinesia make this diagnosis unlikely. Also, improvement of symptoms after walking (no postural instability) further helps rule out this diagnosis.

Option C: Postural hypotension is unlikely as this patient does not complain of dizziness or loss of consciousness immediately after standing and not tremors that appear on standing and disappear during ambulation.

Option D: Physiological tremor is typically detectable through auxiliary testing due to its minimal amplitude which is caused due to the inherent frequency of muscle stretch responses. Several metabolic conditions, such as hypoglycemia, hyperthyroidism, and ethanol withdrawal syndrome, have the potential to exacerbate physiological tremor to the extent that it becomes visibly apparent. This patient's history of tremor and increases on standing which relieves on walking is characteristic of orthostatic tremor.

Dystonic, psychogenic and cerebellar tremors have variable frequency and amplitude. Holmes's tremor is attributed to midbrain impairment and encompasses both rest and postural tremors, characterized by a relatively low frequency.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with a tremor in both hands that worsens while trying to eat or write something. It gets worse when he is stressed and reduces when he drinks wine. His father also had similar symptoms. He is currently being treated with low-dose hydroxychloroquine for porphyria cutanea tarda. On examination, there are no resting tremors. Which of the following drugs can be used to control this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of essential tremors, and the most appropriate drug for this patient's condition is propranolol as he is a known case of porphyria cutanea tarda in whom primidone is contraindicated.

Essential tremor (ET) is the most prevalent movement disorder. Although it can appear in children, its prevalence increases in people aged over 70 years. It is characterized by high-frequency tremors (6–10 Hz), most commonly involving the upper extremities. These tremors are usually symmetrical and bilateral. These tremors manifest when the person is trying to do some activity and are typically made worse by stress and improved by alcohol. Approximately half the patients with ET have a positive family history.

Severe ET may present as intention tremor characterized by overshoot and slow movements, indicating the cerebellar origin of this disorder. 

The drugs used to treat essential tremors are as follows:

  • Primidone and beta blockers - standard therapy; as beta-blockers (e.g. propranolol) are contraindicated in asthma and bradycardia
  • Gabapentin and topiramate- use has not been widespread
  • Botulinum toxin injections for limb or vocal tremors - may result in muscle weakening
  • Surgical treatments targetting the ventral-intermediate (VIM) nucleus of the thalamus - For severe and drug-resistant instances

Note: Essential tremor can be differentiated from Parkinson's disease by the following features: This patient has bilateral tremors on trying to do voluntary activities and his handwriting has become larger. In contrast, in Parkinson's disease, tremors typically begin in one hand, would stop at the onset of voluntary action, and patients usually develop micrographia (small handwriting).

The drugs used to treat essential tremors are:

  • Beta-blockers: propranolol, atenolol
  • Anticonvulsants:
    • Primidone
    • Gabapentine
    • Topiramate

In severe and drug-resistant cases, surgical treatment involves targeting the ventral intermediate (VIM) nucleus of the thalamus.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics of the Parkinsonian tremor is true?

choices.text: Tremor increases during periods of REM sleep
Tremor improves when the patient walks
Tremor of tongue is commonly seen

questions.solution:
Tremor associated with Parkinson's disease (PD) is almost always asymmetric and is very important to help distinguish it from other kinds of tremors.

Parkinsonian tremors have the following characteristics:

  • It is almost always asymmetric
  • Tremor has a frequency of 3-5 Hz
  • Tremor is almost always seen in the hand and forearms with rare occurrences in the feet, jaw, lips and tongue.
  • At the time of presentation is more commonly unilateral
  • Lack of relation between the intensity of tremor and rigidity or bradykinesia.
  • Tremor worsens as the patient walks (unlike in essential tremor)
  • Tremor reduces during REM sleep
  • Interestingly tremors in patients with parkinsonism rarely spill any coffee contained in a cup while drinking a cup of coffee. (According to Adam and Victor's Principles of Neurology)
  • Tremors can be associated with tremors of high frequency such as essential tremors.

PD is characterized by the following four cardinal motor features. Note that Parkinsonism is a broad term that is used when bradykinesia, rigidity and/or tremor are present together. 

  1. Resting tremor 
  2. Asymmetrical rigidity 
  3. Bradykinesia
  4. Dysfunction of the gait and postural instability

Although atypical parkinsonism syndromes (such as multiple system atrophy, progressive supranuclear palsy, and corticobasal degeneration) also present with features of parkinsonism, they differ from PD in that they have a more aggressive course, the motor symptoms symmetrically involve both halves of the body, and tremors are usually absent.

The non-motor manifestations of PD include:

  • Anosmia
  • Sensory symptoms such as pain
  • Mood disorders such as depression
  • Sleep disturbances
  • Autonomic issues: orthostatic hypotension, GI disturbances, sexual dysfunction
  • Dementia

In a patient with parkinsonian features, the presence of visual hallucinations points to a diagnosis of dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB). DLB is characterized by the emergence of neuropsychiatric manifestations before or at the same time as motor manifestations. However, in Parkinson's disease dementia, the cognitive decline occurs many years after the motor symptoms have appeared.

questions.text: A 10 year old boy is brought by his mother with complaints of involuntary chin movements that increase before writing his exams which cannot be initiated or voluntarily suppressed. All other neurological findings were normal. No simultaneous involuntary jaw, facial, head, or other body movements were observed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with involuntary movement of the chin that is precipitated during moments of stress and cannot be voluntarily suppressed is most likely as diagnosis of geniospasm.

Geniospasm is an autosomal dominant disorder. It is a benign genetic condition that manifests only with chin tremors and is known by other names such as hereditary quivering of the chin and hereditary essential chin myoclonus. The presence of chin tremor can be observed in individuals diagnosed with hereditary chin tremor (HCT) during childhood, with its intensity reaching a maximum during the early stages of adulthood and tapering intensity with age.

One of the primary characteristics of essential tremor (ET) is its intermittent manifestation, which is typically induced by emotional stress or worry and lasts for a duration ranging from a few seconds to several hours. The frequency range of HCT exhibits variability, spanning from 2 to 11 Hz. This condition often has a non-progressive nature and lacks any enduring complications. Local injections of botulinum toxin are an effective treatment for this condition. 

Other options

Option A: Tics are semi-voluntary neuropsychiatric events characterized by brief rapid motor movements or vocalizations. These are typically performed in response to irresistible premonitory urges. It usually occurs following an impulse unlike in this patient where the tremors have a lack of control both during initiation and cessation.

Option B: Facial myokymia has similar electromyographic patterns but is more common in patients with brain stem tumours or multiple sclerosis. Also, patients with facial myokymia have usually one side of their face affected.

Option D: Jaw tremor involves the masseter muscle and not the chin as in this patient. Also, this tremor is associated with other postural tremors such as tremors of the limbs and head.

Dystonic, psychogenic, and cerebellar tremors have variable frequency and amplitude.

Holmes's tremor is attributed to midbrain impairment and encompasses both rest and postural tremors, characterized by a relatively low frequency. Typically, it manifests many months after the first acute incident. The condition typically exhibits a significant magnitude of amplitude and renders the affected limb(s) effectively nonfunctional. Due to its rarity, the current therapeutic approach for managing Holmes tremor involves the administration of high-dose levodopa, with dosages reaching up to 750 mg per day.

questions.text: A 7-month-old male child is brought to you by his mother with increasing tremors over the head, neck, and upper limbs with reduced feeding and relative inactivity. There is no history of loss of consciousness or seizures. Hyperpigmented knees and hypopigmented scalp hair were observed. Development age was 2 months in all domains. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with increasing tremors in the head, neck and upper limb along with hyperpigmented knees and hypopigmented scalp hair suggests a diagnosis of infantile tremor syndrome.

Infantile tremor syndrome is seen in a specific group of Indian newborns who are exclusively breastfed. These infants often exhibited symptoms between the ages of 8 and 18 months, including listlessness, developmental delay and regression, pallor, depigmented scanty hair, and hyperpigmented knuckles. Following the initial manifestation, further symptoms encompass the gradual onset of limb tremors, vocalizations resembling the sound of a bleating cry, and the adoption of a bodily posture reminiscent of a bird poised for flight. The aforementioned ailment is associated with a cobalamin deficiency and exhibits a positive response to treatment involving the administration of cobalamin and propranolol.

Other options:

Option B: Huntington's chorea is a trinucleotide (CAG) repeat disorder with an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance. It is characterized by involuntary movements known as chorea.

Option C: Glutaric aciduria is an autosomal recessive disease that manifests in the 1st year of life. It is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glutaryl-CoA dehydrogenase. Clinical features are hypotonia and jitteriness at birth, progressive hyperkinetic movements (dystonia, choreoathetosis), and may have seizures. 

Option D: Lennox-Gastaut syndrome usually starts between the age of 2 and 10 years. It consists of a triad of Developmental delay, Multiple seizure types (including atypical absences, myoclonic, astatic, and tonic seizures) and characteristic EEG findings (1–2 Hz spike and slow waves).

questions.text: A young man presented with symmetric weakness in both the lower limbs for 3 months. The patient also has bilateral upper limb tremors. On examination, reduced power in the proximal muscles of the lower limbs along with loss of deep tendon reflexes was noted. Suppression of tremor was elicited when loaded with a weight. Antibody testing was positive for anti‐neurofascin‐155 (NF155) antibodies.  What is the most likely cause of this patient's tremor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) with this patient's tremor characteristic to that of an entity known as tremor polyneuropathy.

Patients with polyneuropathy very commonly develop tremors which very closely simulate coarse essential or ataxic tremors. They are caused due to IgM antibodies developing against the myelin associated glycoprotein and are found among patients with CIDP and paraproteinemias. Unlike other causes of organic tremors, the tremor associated with polyneuropathy sees a reduction following the loading test. Also, antibodies positive for neurofascin-155 are very closely related to tremor polyneuropathy associated with CIDP, thus making this diagnosis very likely. The tremor is characterised by a low frequency, and high amplitude with both positional and intentional components.

CIDP is an autoimmune condition. It has a chronic course with an onset of >9 weeks when compared with Guillain Barre syndrome (GBS) which has an acute onset. However, both CIDP and GBS have similar presenting features.

The clinical features include symmetric proximal weakness. If there is involvement of the cranial nerves, external ophthalmoplegia may be seen. Some patients may also present with isolated motor or sensory involvement. If sensory involvement is present it can be seen as chronic inflammatory sensory polyradiculopathy (CISP)  or distal acquired demyelinating symmetric (DADS) variants. 

CSF is usually acellular and shows elevated protein levels. Presence of conduction blocks is a certain sign of an acquired demyelinating process. Other features that may or may not be seen in nerve conduction studies are:

  • conduction slowing (option B)
  • prolonged distal latencies (option C),
  • distal and temporal dispersion of compound muscle action potential (CMAP).
  • axonal loss (option D) can be seen secondary to demyelination.

In mild cases, expectant management is suitable. Treatment is initially started with IV immunoglobulins. Other options include glucocorticoids, plasmapheresis, and immunosuppressants. 

Other options:

Option B: Athetosis is common among patients with hepatic encephalopathy and is characterized by distinct, writhing motions, particularly evident in the fingers and limbs.

Option C: Essential tremor (ET) is the most prevalent movement disorder. Although it can appear in children, its prevalence increases in people aged over 70 years. It is characterized by high-frequency tremors (6–10 Hz), most commonly involving the upper extremities. These tremors are usually symmetrical and bilateral. These tremors manifest when the person is trying to do some activity and are typically made worse by stress and improved by alcohol. Approximately half the patients with ET have a positive family history. 

Option D: Intentional tremors are seen in cerebellar diseases and are known to increase during goal-directed activity.

questions.text: The occurrence of recurrent and regular contraction of a muscle that is subjected to a quick and sustained stretch,  accurately defines which of the following?
questions.solution:
Clonus is defined as the occurrence of recurrent/repetitive and regular contraction of a muscle that is subjected to a quick and sustained stretch.

Clonus is seen in states with high gamma motor neuron activity. It is a rhythmic oscillatory series of muscle contractions that is induced by stretching the tendon. It can be elicited in many joints but is most commonly seen in the ankle joint by suddenly dorsiflexing the foot and maintaining light upward pressure. It is seen in UMN lesions and is associated with other signs of UMN lesions like spasticity. A sustained clonus of five or more beats is considered abnormal.

The management of clonus frequently revolves around addressing its underlying aetiology. In certain cases, the implementation of physical therapy with stretching exercises has been observed to mitigate occurrences of clonus. Immunosuppressive agents such as azathioprine and corticosteroids, anticonvulsants including primidone, levetiracetam and clonazepam, have demonstrated efficacy in the therapeutic management of clonus. Botulinum toxin has been employed as a means to inhibit the release of acetylcholine in the muscle, hence impeding the occurrence of rhythmic muscular contractions commonly associated with clonus.

Other options 

Option A: Athetosis is characterised by writhing and sinuous movements, particularly noticeable in the digits and extremities and is seen in patients with hepatic encephalopathy.

Option B: Tremor can be defined as involuntary motions with no intent caused by alternating contractions of opposing/antagonistic muscle groups. 

Option D: Asterixis is defined as an intermittency of maintained posture in patients with hepatic encephalopathy, gravity and the inherent elasticity of muscles produce the movement which the patient attempts to correct but then overshoots leading to this movement disorder.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a tremor that has distorted his handwriting over the past 2 months. He is a known asthmatic on a salbutamol inhaler for the past 15 years. He also underwent liver transplantation 5 months ago and is on tacrolimus. On examination, a coarse tremor is noticeable. The rest of his CNS examination is normal. What should be done to manage his tremor?
questions.solution:
This patient with coarse tremors a few months after liver transplantation and who is on tacrolimus is most likely suffering from tacrolimus-induced tremors that resolve with tacrolimus dose reduction. 

Although salbutamol is also known to cause tremors but is commonly seen during the first few days to weeks following salbutamol inhaltion, which later meets reduction due to tolerance. It is also important to note that salbutamol induced tremors are finer than those caused by tacrolimus.

Tacrolimus and cyclosporine are calcineurin inhibitors and are the common agents used for immunosuppression following liver transplantation. They are metabolized by the CYP3A enzyme. Calcineurin is a calcium/calmodulin-dependent phosphatase required for the induction of T-cell lymphokine production and proliferation. Cyclosporine is an immunomodulatory drug that inhibits calcineurin activity by forming a complex with cyclophilin, a cytoplasmic-receptor protein present in target cells, to form a cyclosporine-cyclophilin complex.

This drug-receptor complex specifically and competitively binds to and inhibits calcineurin, a calcium and calmodulin-dependent phosphatase. This in turn, inhibits the translocation of a family of transcription factors (NF-AT), leading to reduced transcriptional activation of cytokine genes for interleukin (IL)-2, tumour necrosis factor (TNF)-alpha, IL-3, IL-4, CD40L, granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor, and interferon-gamma. Ultimately, the proliferation of T lymphocytes is reduced, resulting in immunomodulation.

Its uses are :

  • In solid organ transplantation, to treat organ rejection in kidney, liver, and heart allogeneic transplants.
  • In patients with rheumatoid arthritis, when the disease has not adequately responded to methotrexate.
  • It is approved to treat amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS or Lou Gehrig disease) and its variants.
  • In nephrotic syndrome, to treat focal segmental glomerulosclerosis not responding to corticosteroids.

Adverse effects of cyclosporine include a decrease in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and metabolic disturbances like hypomagnesemia, hyperkalemia, dyslipidemia, gynecomastia, hypertrichosis; neurotoxicity in the form of convulsions. There is an increased risk of developing skin and lymphoproliferative malignancies in cyclosporine-treated psoriasis patients.

Other options

Option A: Tremors due to β2 agonists can be both due to direct action on muscle spindle and hypokalemia. Initially, it was thought to be due to beta receptor-mediated enhancement of discharge of muscle spindles. However, recently the tremors have also been closely correlated with hypokalemia. Hence, direct action and hypokalemia can explain the tremors associated with β2 agonist use, although the exact mechanism is still unknown. The tremors associated with salbutamol are known to achieve tolerance or reduction after a few days to weeks of doses and are also known to be less coarse than that of a tremor induced by tacrolimus.

Option B: L-DOPA can be prescribed in patients with Parkinson's disease(PD) in whom the tremor associated is almost always asymmetric and is very important to help distinguish it from other kinds of tremors. PD is characterized by four cardinal motor features ie, resting tremor, Asymmetrical, rigidity, bradykinesia and dysfunction of the gait with postural instability.

Option D: Trihexyphenidyl is an anticholinergic drug which is also prescribed in patients with Parkinson's disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with fine tremors of her hands for the past 6 months with associated weight loss and palpitations. Examination reveals a staring gaze, warm extremities as well and a postural tremor involving both her hands. Her tremor can be appropriately termed as?
questions.solution:
Based on the above clinical history the patient has hyperthyroidism, and the tremor she has is known as an enhanced physiologic tremor.

Enhanced physiologic tremor can be noticed in persons with normal physiological functioning during periods of heightened muscle activity, such as during exercise or shortly following it. This phenomenon is likely associated with an increase in sympathetic activity. The aforementioned condition is classified as an action tremor, characterized by its subtle nature that may not be easily discernible without the aid of magnification due to its small range of motion and rapid oscillations at a frequency of 8-12 Hz (which may be slower in infants and the elderly). It manifests bilaterally and symmetrically, affecting both hands and all fingers.

This type of tremor is frequently recognized as a postural tremor and is considered to be one of the most regularly encountered forms. Patients with reflex sympathetic dystrophy have been found to exhibit a unilateral postural tremor that resembles an increased physiologic tremor. In cases where the tremor is not readily discernible, it is possible to enhance its visibility by positioning a sheet of paper atop the extended hands.

Factors such as intense physical activity, tiredness, feelings of unease, heightened stress levels, excessive intake of caffeine, alcohol, valproate, lithium and medical diseases related to an accelerated metabolic rate, such as hyperthyroidism, can contribute to the heightened visibility of the Enhanced physiologic tremor.

Treatment includes managing the underlying condition, however, if necessary propranolol has also been proven effective.

Other options:

Option A: Task-specific tremors are usually seen when people perform during certain tasks such as while playing music or writing but are absent in other forms of work. This patient's tremor is seen both at rest and while maintaining posture which along with signs of hyperthyroidism favours this tremor to be deemed as an Enhanced physiologic tremor.

Option C: Essential tremor (ET) is the most prevalent movement disorder. Although it can appear in children, its prevalence increases in people aged over 70 years. It is characterized by high-frequency tremors (6–10 Hz), most commonly involving the upper extremities. These tremors are usually symmetrical and bilateral. These tremors manifest when the person is trying to do some activity and are typically made worse by stress and improved by alcohol. This patient's tremor is seen both at rest and while maintaining posture which along with signs of hyperthyroidism favours this tremor to be deemed as an Enhanced physiologic tremor.

Option D: Physiological tremor is typically detectable through auxiliary testing due to its minimal amplitude which is caused due to the inherent frequency of muscle stretch responses. Several metabolic conditions, such as hypoglycemia, hyperthyroidism, and ethanol withdrawal syndrome, have the potential to exacerbate physiological tremor to the extent that it becomes visibly apparent. This patient's tremor is seen both at rest and while maintaining posture which along with signs of hyperthyroidism favours this tremor to be deemed as an Enhanced physiologic tremor.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old child on salbutamol is brought to the hospital with complaints of tremors. Which of the following effects of the drug would explain this side effect?
  1. Direct action on muscle spindles
  2. Hypokalemia
  3. Hyperkalemia
  4. Direct action at the motor end-plate
  5. Hypoglycemia
questions.solution:
Tremors due to β2 agonists can be both due to direct action on muscle spindle and hypokalemia.

Initially, it was thought to be due to beta receptor-mediated enhancement of discharge of muscle spindles. However, recently the tremors have also been closely correlated with hypokalemia. Hence both direct action and hypokalemia can explain the tremors associated with β2 agonist use, although the exact mechanism is still not known.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to you with complaints of tremors in his right hand only while playing his guitar which has progressively increased over the past few months. There were no other neurologic symptoms. He can perform his other daily chores at home with no difficulty. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's tremor which is only seen while playing the guitar and his ability to perform his daily tasks without any limitation along with a normal neurological examination, helps us diagnose this patient with task-specific tremor.

Task-specific tremors are usually seen when people perform certain tasks such as while playing music or writing but are absent in other forms of work.

Primary writing tremor (PWT) is the most common task-specific tremor. The condition is characterized by an involuntary shaking of the hand specifically during the act of writing or when attempting to write. The classification of PWT is based on the temporal occurrence of the tremor, distinguishing between type-A (tremor during the act of writing) and type-B (tremor while assuming the hand position often employed for writing). Therefore, it may be concluded that type-B PWT is characterized by a tremor that is particular to certain positions rather than being only task-specific.

Numerous studies have posited a potential involvement of the cerebellum in the development of PWT. Numerous instances of task-specific tremors have been documented in the literature. These include task-specific tremors observed in musicians, oro-lingual tremors only during the act of drinking,  chin tremors solely during tooth brushing and finger tremors observed in carrom players. There are also reports indicating that a subset of these people subsequently manifests symptoms of Parkinson's disease. 

Treatment of patients with task-specific tremors includes propranolol, trihexylphenydyl and primidone.

Other options:

Option A: Enhanced physiologic tremor, an action tremor, occurs during or shortly after exercise due to increased sympathetic activity. It features subtle, rapid oscillations at 8-12 Hz (can be slower in infants and the elderly) and affects both hands and fingers symmetrically. Often recognized as a postural tremor, it is one of the most common tremor types.

Option C: Essential tremor (ET) is the most common movement disorder, especially prevalent in those over 70. It involves high-frequency tremors (6–10 Hz) that typically affect the upper extremities symmetrically and bilaterally. These tremors occur during activity, worsen with stress, and often improve with alcohol. It can be familial. 

Option D: Physiological tremor, usually detectable only through testing due to its minimal amplitude, arises from the inherent frequency of muscle stretch responses. It can become visibly apparent when exacerbated by metabolic conditions such as hypoglycemia, hyperthyroidism, or ethanol withdrawal syndrome.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with fibromyalgia on amitriptyline presents to you with sudden onset tremors in her right arm which decrease the moment you ask her to lift her left arm. What kind of tremor is she experiencing?
questions.solution:
This patient with fibromyalgia is most likely having a psychogenic tremor which is known to reduce in frequency and amplitude upon distracting the patient.

Individuals diagnosed with psychogenic/functional tremors exhibit a higher likelihood of experiencing abrupt onset, spontaneous remissions, shorter duration of tremor, and a lower incidence of familial history of tremor. Moreover, it was observed that individuals diagnosed with functional tremors exhibited a higher degree of distractibility during tasks involving alternate finger tapping and mental attention.

Additionally, they displayed increased amplitude when exposed to a tuning fork, and experienced a worsening of symptoms when engaging in hyperventilation. Functional tremors have the potential to impact several regions of the body, however, it is well observed that the hands are the most frequently affected area in cases of functional tremors. The presence of tremors in various body parts, exhibiting coherence in their frequencies, serves as an indication of functional tremor.

A meticulous evaluation of these characteristics can aid in differentiating functional tremor from other prevalent conditions characterized by tremors, such as essential tremor (ET) and Parkinson's disease (PD). They are found to be common among patients with major depressive disorder, fibromyalgia, irritable bowel syndrome and other psychiatric conditions.

Fibromyalgia is characterized by chronic widespread musculoskeletal pain and tenderness accompanied by other non-specific somatic symptoms like fatigue and sleep disturbance, for >three months. 

It is more common in females. On examination, they have tenderness in multiple soft tissue anatomical locations. Laboratory findings are normal. 

Patients with fibromyalgia may have an increased prevalence of other syndromes associated with pain and fatigue, like chronic headaches, chronic fatigue syndrome, irritable bowel syndrome, interstitial cystitis/ painful bladder syndrome, and pelvic pain syndromes.

Other options:

Option A: Intentional tremors are seen in cerebellar diseases and are known to increase during goal-directed activity. These tremors are not known to reduce once the patient is distracted. 

Option B: Drug-induced tremors are common following consumption of drugs that belong to classes such as tricyclic antidepressants, aminophyllines, beta-2 agonists, and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors(to name a few). These tremors are not known to reduce once the patient is distracted. 

Option C: Physiological tremor is typically detectable through auxiliary testing due to its minimal amplitude which is caused due to the inherent frequency of muscle stretch responses. Several metabolic conditions, such as hypoglycemia, hyperthyroidism, and ethanol withdrawal syndrome, have the potential to exacerbate physiological tremor to the extent that it becomes visibly apparent. These tremors are not known to reduce once the patient is distracted.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to you with tremors in her right upper limb and cervical region. During these episodes of tremors, it was noticed that she turned her head towards the right with concomitant mild generalised stiffness. Her cranial nerve examination reported no abnormal findings. However, on attempting to turn the head to the left, her tremor and stiffness improved.  What is the type of tremor she is most likely experiencing?
questions.solution:
The presence of tremor in a patient, accompanied by concurrent dystonia in the same limb, which persists during tremor episodes and improves when attempting to push the head to the left, is indicative of dystonic tremor. 

Dystonic tremor (DT) is characterized by the presence of dystonia as the primary neurological manifestation, with tremor occurring in the specific body region affected by dystonia. When a patient diagnosed with dystonia experiences a tremor in a body region that is not affected by dystonia, it is referred to as a "tremor associated with dystonia" (TAWD). On certain occasions, patients can experience delirium tremens (DT) in addition to withdrawal from alcohol dependence (TAWD). Although dystonia can manifest in various body parts, it is commonly observed in individuals with cervical dystonia, often presenting as head tremors.

Dystonia (DT) can be mitigated or eradicated through the performance of a manoeuvre, also known as "sensory trick" or "geste antagoniste." Additionally, when the affected body part is positioned in the direction of dystonia and the movement, tremor, or abnormal posture ceases, this is commonly referred to as the "null point." On the other hand, the intensity of dystonic tremor (DT) escalates when the affected body part is deliberately positioned in opposition to the primary direction of dystonia-induced contraction. For instance, a patient experiencing right torticollis may experience an exacerbation of DT when rotating the head towards the left or attempting to sustain the primary posture of the head.

Other options:

Option A: Intentional tremors are seen in cerebellar diseases and are known to increase during goal-directed activity. These tremors are not known to be associated with concomitant dystonia.

Option B: Individuals diagnosed with psychogenic/functional tremors exhibit a higher likelihood of experiencing abrupt onset, spontaneous remissions, shorter duration of tremor, and a lower incidence of familial history of tremor. Moreover, it was observed that individuals diagnosed with functional tremors exhibited a higher degree of distractibility during tasks involving alternate finger tapping and mental attention. Additionally, they displayed increased amplitude when exposed to a tuning fork, and experienced a worsening of symptoms when engaging in hyperventilation. These tremors are not known to be associated with concomitant dystonia.

Option C: Physiological tremor is typically detectable through auxiliary testing due to its minimal amplitude which is caused due to the inherent frequency of muscle stretch responses. Several metabolic conditions, such as hypoglycemia, hyperthyroidism, and ethanol withdrawal syndrome, have the potential to exacerbate physiological tremor to the extent that it becomes visibly apparent. These tremors are not known to be associated with concomitant dystonia.

questions.text: The observance of increasing spillage of water while a man takes a mug of water from one bucket and pours it into another can be categorized as which type of tremor?
questions.solution:
Increasing spillage of water while moving from one point to another is characteristic of kinetic tremor.

Patients with kinetic tremors have increasing tremors throughout a goal-directed activity. 

Resting tremor Postural tremor Intention tremors
Parkinson's disease Physiological  Trauma
Holmes tremor Exaggerated physiological tremor Drugs or toxins
Wilson's disease Orthostatic Diseases of cerebellar outflow (dentate nucleus or interpositus nuclei)
Essential tremor Associated with peripheral neuropathy (Charcot Marie Tooth)  


Other options:

Option A: Resting tremors are tremors that occur at rest and reduce in intensity during movement. Hence, reduced spillage of water during movement of water from point A to point B.

Option B: Postural tremors occur during a fixed posture against gravity. Hence, increased spillage of water while staying still and holding a glass of water.

Option C: Terminal tremor occurs during the end of an activity. Hence, increased spillage of water as he or she attempts to place water on the table.

questions.text: The observance of increased spillage of water as a man holds a glass of water given to him indicates which type of tremor?
questions.solution:
Increasing spillage of water as a man holds a glass of water in his hands can be seen in postural tremors. 

Postural tremors occur during a fixed posture against gravity. Hence, increased spillage of water while staying still and holding a glass of water.

Resting tremor Postural tremor Intention tremors
Parkinson's disease Physiological  Trauma
Holmes tremor Exaggerated physiological tremor Drugs or toxins
Wilson's disease Orthostatic Diseases of cerebellar outflow (dentate nucleus or interpositus nuclei)
Essential tremor Associated with peripheral neuropathy (Charcot Marie Tooth)  

Action tremors manifest during the execution of certain tasks. Action tremors can be classified into various subtypes, namely postural, kinetic, task-specific, and isometric. Action tremors are only observed at rest when they are severe.

Postural tremors manifest when the limbs are held in an antigravity posture, such as when the arms are extended outward. The prevalent forms of postural tremor include increased physiologic tremor and essential tremor (ET).

Kinetic tremor manifests during the execution of a deliberate motor action and can manifest at many stages of the movement, including its initiation, progression, or termination. One prevalent illustration is an intentional (terminal) tremor.

Intention tremor is a type of action tremor that is predominantly observed in individuals with cerebellar disease. The tremor manifests when a high level of precision is necessary to successfully make contact with a specific target, such as in the finger-nose-finger or toe-to-finger examination.

Other options 

Option A: Resting tremors are tremors that occur at rest and reduce in intensity during movement. Hence, reduced spillage of water during the movement of water from point A to point B or even holding the glass (as he is still opposing gravity).

Option B: Patients with kinetic tremors have increasing tremors throughout a goal-directed activity. Increasing spillage of water while moving from one point to another is characteristic of kinetic tremor. 

Option C: Terminal tremors occur during the end of an activity. Hence, increased spillage of water as he or she attempts to place water on the table.

questions.text:
Match the following
A- Wing beating tremor 1- Midbrain damage
B- Rosenbach's sign 2- Wilson's disease
C- Holme's tremor 3- Mercury poisoning
D- Danbury tremor 4- Hyperthyroidism
questions.solution:
Wing beating tremor Wilson's disease
Rosenbach's sign Hyperthyroidism
Holme's tremor Midbrain damage
Danbury tremor Mercury poisoning

Late coarse tremors have been described as wing-beating tremors in Wilson's disease

Rosenbach's sign is fine tremors on attempted closure of the eyelids.

Holmes's tremor is attributed to midbrain impairment and encompasses both rest and postural tremors, characterized by a relatively low frequency.

Danbury tremors are coarse, intentional tremors. The advanced condition is called Hatter's shakes/Glass blower's shakes and are seen in patients with mercuric poisoning.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with abnormal movements of the limbs. A lesion of the globus pallidus is suspected. Which of the following did she most likely present with?
questions.solution:
This woman with a lesion at the globus pallidus most likely presented with athetosis: Slow, writhing movements of a hand/arm/the face. 

Condition Site of lesion Description 
Chorea Striatum

Flicking movements in the hands, face, and other parts of the body
Athetosis Globus pallidus

Spontaneous, continuous writhing movements of a hand, an arm, the neck, or the face
Hemiballusmus Subthalamic nucleus

Sudden flailing movements of an entire limb
Parkinsonism Substantia nigra

Severe rigidity, akinesia, and tremors

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl exhibits rapid, semi-purposeful, graceful, dance-like, involuntary movements. What is this finding?
questions.solution:
Rapid, semi-purposeful, graceful, dance-like, involuntary movements are seen in chorea.

Hyperkinetic movement disorders:

Tremor

Rhythmic oscillation of a body part due to intermittent muscle contractions

Dystonia

Involuntary, sustained or repeated muscle contractions often associated with twisting movements and abnormal posture

Athetosis

Slow, distal, writhing, involuntary movements with a propensity to affect arms and hands

Chorea

Rapid, semi-purposeful, graceful, dance-like, non patterned, involuntary movements involving distal or proximal muscle groups

Myoclonus

Sudden, brief (<100ms), jerk-like arrhythmic muscle twitches

Tics

Brief, repeated, stereotyped muscle contractions that can often be suppressed for a short time

Sydenham's chorea (also called St. Vitus's dance) is a type of chorea that is typically seen in childhood (5-15 years) with prior exposure to group A streptococcal infection and is thought to be autoimmune in nature. It is characterized by the acute onset of choreiform movements and behavioral disturbances and is self-limiting.
